4140/A0/05/300/301.indicator_name: Number of national standards  implementation strategies and guidelines endorsed for child-centred inclusive education
4140/A0/05/300/301.headline: Strategies and standard guidelines have been put in place for school infrastructure support and the self-learning programme. UNICEF has made advocacy efforts and induction sessions on these strategies and guidelines with the Ministry of Education  leading to the government endorsement.

4140/A0/05/300/301.indicator_name: Number of MoE/DoE officials and school staff benefitting from professional development
4140/A0/05/300/301.headline: Strategies and standard guidelines have been put in place for school infrastructure support and the self-learning programme. UNICEF has made advocacy efforts and induction sessions on these strategies and guidelines with the Ministry of Education  leading to the government endorsement.

4140/A0/05/300/303.indicator_name: Number of children enrolled in non-formal education
4140/A0/05/300/303.headline: For the academic year 2016/17  UNICEF reached 2 580 798 children with BTL education supplies  such as textbooks  school bags and stationery. 6.5 million people were reached with BTL media campaign and face-to-face social mobilisation. Efforts were also made for school infrastructure assistance  ECCE  teacher training  as well as non-formal education.

4140/A0/05/300/303.indicator_name: Number of children benefitting from formal education
4140/A0/05/300/303.headline: For the academic year 2016/17  UNICEF reached 2 580 798 children with BTL education supplies  such as textbooks  school bags and stationery. 6.5 million people were reached with BTL media campaign and face-to-face social mobilisation. Efforts were also made for school infrastructure assistance  ECCE  teacher training  as well as non-formal education.

4140/A0/05/300/303.indicator_name: Number of children benefitting from self-learning and remedial education
4140/A0/05/300/303.headline: For the academic year 2016/17  UNICEF reached 2 580 798 children with BTL education supplies  such as textbooks  school bags and stationery. 6.5 million people were reached with BTL media campaign and face-to-face social mobilisation. Efforts were also made for school infrastructure assistance  ECCE  teacher training  as well as non-formal education.

4140/A0/05/300/302.indicator_name: National Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan (EPRP) for education and governorate-level action plans endorsed and operationalised by MoE and DoEs
4140/A0/05/300/302.headline: Capacity development in emergency preparedness and response plan was undertaken at the sector level. As part of institutional capacity development  UNICEF collaborated with the MOE/DOEs and UNESCO to improve EMIS data collection and analysis. The end-user assessment for the self-learning programme was also undertaken for quality assurance and donor accountability.

4140/A0/05/300/302.indicator_name: Number of sector partners equipped with capacities in education emergency responses and early recovery
4140/A0/05/300/302.headline: Capacity development in emergency preparedness and response plan was undertaken at the sector level. As part of institutional capacity development  UNICEF collaborated with the MOE/DOEs and UNESCO to improve EMIS data collection and analysis. The end-user assessment for the self-learning programme was also undertaken for quality assurance and donor accountability.

4140/A0/05/400/401.headline: Limited progress towards the development of a draft outline of Plan of Action on adolescent development  however  consorted efforts to build local capacity of youth volunteers to deliver resilience and social cohesion programming for adolescents progressed well.

4140/A0/05/400/401.indicator_name: Multi-Sectoral National Framework of Action on Adolescent and Youth Development and Participation approved

4140/A0/05/400/402.indicator_name: Number of adolescents and youth who accessed a comprehensive package of adolescent and youth services
4140/A0/05/400/402.headline: Positive opportunities for fostering of resilience and social cohesion through equitable access to quality learning  development and meaningful participation provided at scale for the most vulnerable young girls and boys across Syria.

4140/A0/05/400/402.indicator_name: Number of affected youth receiving seed funding and who have implemented social and business entrepreneurship initiatives
4140/A0/05/400/402.headline: Positive opportunities for fostering of resilience and social cohesion through equitable access to quality learning  development and meaningful participation provided at scale for the most vulnerable young girls and boys across Syria.

4140/PC/07/884/003.indicator_name: # of women reached with health education activities
4140/PC/07/884/003.headline: 160 Mothers in shelters and camps are counselled on proper practices for Infant Young Child Feeding

4140/PC/07/884/002.headline: Mothers and children are supported with micronutrients and therapeutic preventative supplies.

4140/PC/07/884/001.indicator_name: Number of primary health care out-patient consultations
4140/PC/07/884/001.headline: Around 60 000 Palestinian children and women received pediatric and maternal health services through UNICEF supported project in Rural Aleppo by the PLS Red Crescent

4140/A0/05/500/504.indicator_name: Number of individuals reached with awareness raising initiatives on child protection issues
4140/A0/05/500/504.headline: Advocacy efforts have been scaled-up at inter-sectoral level to ensure the adequate attention to grave violation of children&#39 s rights  and continuous negotiations on increased access to children most at risk. The development of response mechanisms to address child recruitment is a major milestone in the enhancement of child protection interventions

4140/A0/05/500/501.indicator_name: Number of policies  plans and guidelines developed to scale up child protection interventions
4140/A0/05/500/501.headline: Discussions with National counterparts for the development of responses to major protection issues continued and led to the definition of an initial plan of interventions for addressing children engaged in worst forms of child labour and  an enhanced response to child trafficking

4140/A0/05/500/503.indicator_name: Number of governorates with case management and referral mechanism operational
4140/A0/05/500/503.headline: While preparations are ongoing to roll up methods and tools to ensure case management and referral mechanism  the expansion of qualified provision of psychosocial support continues to provide the primary response to children affected by the conflict and in need of protection

4140/A0/05/500/503.indicator_name: Number of girls  boys  women and men participating in structured and sustained child protection and psychosocial support programmes  including parenting programmes
4140/A0/05/500/503.headline: While preparations are ongoing to roll up methods and tools to ensure case management and referral mechanism  the expansion of qualified provision of psychosocial support continues to provide the primary response to children affected by the conflict and in need of protection

4140/A0/05/500/502.indicator_name: Number of child protection workers and volunteers trained in child protection (including case management and family tracing)
4140/A0/05/500/502.headline: Through an intensive dialogue with national counterparts  a comprehensive model of integrated social services has been defined  focusing on innovative methodologies for case management and referral mechanisms  while sustaining he capacity of service providers engaged daily in the protection of children

4140/A0/05/500/502.indicator_name: Number of people trained in risk education
4140/A0/05/500/502.headline: Through an intensive dialogue with national counterparts  a comprehensive model of integrated social services has been defined  focusing on innovative methodologies for case management and referral mechanisms  while sustaining he capacity of service providers engaged daily in the protection of children

4140/A0/05/200/201.headline: The largest WASH programme partner&#39 s capacity strengthened in WASH programme assessment  planning  implementation and management

4140/A0/05/600/603.indicator_name: Number of families receiving vouchers to procure winter clothes for their children
4140/A0/05/600/603.headline: Blankets and clothes kits was provided to around 500 000 children in 2016  protecting them from the consequences of harsh weather. Children were reached through direct distribution  inter-agency convoys  and distribution of e-vouchers to families for the direct purchase of NFIs where market conditions allow.

4140/A0/05/100/104.headline: About 333 508 mothers were reached by UNICEF with breast-feeding and IYCF counselling to save the lives of children and prevent malnutrition with focus on IDPs and vulnerable communities.

4140/A0/05/100/104.indicator_name: Number of U5 children and women of child-bearing age receiving micronutrients

4140/A0/05/100/101.indicator_name: Number of national health and nutrition policies and strategies developed
4140/A0/05/100/101.headline: With UNICEF support  eight health and nutrition national policies/ strategies were revised to support sustainable quality services to the vulnerable population. Revised policies included integrated management of childhood illnesses  nutrition information system  nutrition strategy  policy  in addition to 2 new policies on neonatal mortality and switching to bOPV.

4140/A0/05/100/103.indicator_name: Number of children under 5 receiving polio vaccination
4140/A0/05/100/103.headline: Syria has been polio free since January 2014  and has adopted the global strategy for SWITCH to the bivalent oral polio vaccine. In 2016  the routine vaccination programmes was sustained with UNICEF support and monthly follow-up meetings in all governorates.

4140/A0/05/100/103.indicator_name: Number of children under 1 receiving measles vaccination
4140/A0/05/100/103.headline: Syria has been polio free since January 2014  and has adopted the global strategy for SWITCH to the bivalent oral polio vaccine. In 2016  the routine vaccination programmes was sustained with UNICEF support and monthly follow-up meetings in all governorates.

4140/A0/05/100/102.indicator_name: Number of primary health care centres in districts rehabilitated
4140/A0/05/100/102.headline: UNICEF provided capacity building and supplies to district health centers to enhance their capacity to provide health services to internally displaced people (IDPs) and vulnerable host communities.  UNICEF also supported small scale rehabilitation to 16 primary health centers (PHCs) to enable them to resume their full capacity to function.

4140/A0/05/100/102.indicator_name: Number of primary health care out-patient consultations
4140/A0/05/100/102.headline: UNICEF provided capacity building and supplies to district health centers to enhance their capacity to provide health services to internally displaced people (IDPs) and vulnerable host communities.  UNICEF also supported small scale rehabilitation to 16 primary health centers (PHCs) to enable them to resume their full capacity to function.

4140/PC/07/885/001.indicator_name: Assessment on the situation of PLS refugees in Syria conducted
4140/PC/07/885/001.headline: A comprehensive Situation Assessment of Palestinian refugees living in Syria  based on MICS methodology  provided up-to-date evidence on the current socio-economic status and needs of Palestinian refugees living in Syria  with a special focus on children and women  for future planning and programming
